title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
Part 1
For each variable, compute the following values. You can use the built-in functions or use the mathematical formulas.

Expected Value
Variance
Standard Deviation


random_vars <- readRDS("../../Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")

# part 1
expected_value_age <- mean(random_vars$age)
expected_value_income <- mean(random_vars$income)

variance_age <- var(random_vars$age)
variance_income <- var(random_vars$income)

std_dev_age <- sd(random_vars$age)
std_dev_income <- sd(random_vars$income)

cat("Expected Values \nAge: ", expected_value_age,"\nIncome: ", expected_value_income)

#> Expected Values 
#> Age:  33.471 
#> Income:  3510.731

cat("Variance \nAge: ", variance_age,"\nIncome: ", variance_income)

#> Variance 
#> Age:  340.6078 
#> Income:  8625646

cat("Standard Deviation \nAge: ", std_dev_age,"\nIncome: ", std_dev_income)

#> Standard Deviation 
#> Age:  18.45556 
#> Income:  2936.945




Part 2
Explain, if it makes sense to compare the standard deviations.

Standard deviation measures the spread or variability of a distribution. If one variable has a much larger standard deviation than another, it indicates greater variability in the data points.
Comparing standard deviations makes sense if the variables are measured in same units. In this example one is age in years and another is salary in currency. Therefore, it is not meaningful in this example to compare standard deviations directly.



Part 3
Then, examine the relationship between both variables and compute: covariance and correlation

Covariance is a measure of how 2 variables vary together. If positive, it suggests that higher values of one variable are associated with higher variables of the other, and vice versa if negative covariance.
Correlation is a standardized measure that indicates the strength and direction of a linear relationship between 2 variables. Ranges from -1 to 1, where -1 indicates a perfect negative linear relationship, +1 indicates a perfect positive linear relationship, and 0 indicates no linear relationship.


covar_age_income <- cov(random_vars$age, random_vars$income)
corr_age_income <- cor(random_vars$age, random_vars$income)

cat("Covariance: ", covar_age_income, "\nCorrelation: ", corr_age_income)

#> Covariance:  29700.15 
#> Correlation:  0.5479432




Part 4
What measure is easier to interpret? Please discuss your interpretation.
From above we see from the value of Covariance is too large and hard to interpret how the variables age and income vary with respect to each other.
As correlation is standardized, ranging from -1 to 1, it is easier to compare the strength and direction of relationships between variables, regardless of the scale or units.
Here, correlation is positive with a value of approximately 0.5479, implying a positive linear relationship between age and income.


Part 5
Compute the conditional expected values for:

E[income | age <= 18]
E[income | age \(\in\) [18, 65)]
E[income | age >= 65]


library(dplyr)

#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

random_vars <- random_vars %>%
  filter(!is.na(income), !is.na(age))

cond_exp_income_age_18 <- random_vars %>%
  filter(age <= 18) %>%
  summarise(mean_income = mean(income)) %>%
  pull(mean_income)

cond_exp_income_age_18_65 <- random_vars %>%
  filter(age >= 18, age < 65) %>%
  summarise(mean_income = mean(income)) %>%
  pull(mean_income)

cond_exp_income_age_65 <- random_vars %>%
  filter(age >= 65) %>%
  summarise(mean_income = mean(income)) %>%
  pull(mean_income)

cat("18 and below: ", cond_exp_income_age_18, "\n18 and 65: ", cond_exp_income_age_18_65, "\n65 above: ", cond_exp_income_age_65)

#> 18 and below:  389.6074 
#> 18 and 65:  4685.734 
#> 65 above:  1777.237

title: Probability Theory
text:
Assignment 1
From the picture: 
We know:
P(S) = 0.3
P(T) = 0.7
P(T | S) = 0.2
P(T | S) = 0.8
P(T | S) = 0.6
P(T | S) = 0.4
Referring to 
The solutions:

P(T ∩ S) = P(S) * P(T | S)
P(T ∩ S) = P(S) * P(T | S)
P(T ∩ S) = P(S) * P(T | S)
P(T ∩ S) = P(S) * P(T | S)


S <- 0.3
TgS <- 0.2 # 0.8 is Tbar given S
TgSbar <- 0.6 # 0.4 is Tbar given Sbar

TandS <- S * TgS
TandSbar <- (1 - S) * TgSbar
TbarandS <- S * (1 - TgS)
TbarandSbar <- (1 - S) * (1 - TgSbar)

print( paste( "Sum: ", ( TandS + TandSbar + TbarandS + TbarandSbar ) ) )

#> [1] "Sum:  1"




Assignment 2



Figure 1: Venn Diagram


From the venn diagram:

The percentage of customers using all three devices is

5 or 0.5% of total customers

The percentage of customers using at least 2 devices

Customers using (Smartphones and Tablets) + (Tablet and Computer) + (Computer and Smartphone) + (all three)
199 or 19.9% of customers

The percentage of customers using only one device

Customers using only smartphone + only Tablet + only computer
801 or 80.1% of customers




Assignment 3
Given:

P(A) = 0.04
P(B|A) = 0.97
P(B|A) = 0.01

To find P(A|B) and P(A|B)

Calculate P(B): \[
P(B) = P(B|A) \cdot P(A) + P(B|\overline{A}) \cdot P(\overline{A})
\]

\[
P(B) = 0.97 \cdot 0.04 + 0.01 \cdot (1 - 0.04) \\
\]
\[
P(B) = 0.0484
\] 2. Apply Bayes’ Theorem:
\[
P(A | B) = \frac{P(B | A) \cdot P(A)}{P(B)} \\
\]
\[
P (A | B) = \frac{0.97 \cdot 0.04}{0.0484}\\
\]
\[
P(A | B) = 0.791
\] Similarly, \[
P(\overline{A} | B) = \frac{P(B | \overline{A}) \cdot P(\overline{A})}{P(B)} \\
\] \[
P (\overline{A} | B) = \frac{0.01 \cdot (1 - 0.04)}{0.0484}\\
\] \[
P(\overline{A} | B) = 0.209
\]
Now subsituting the values to the sentence:
“These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a probability of about 79.1% that the product is flawless and a probability of about 20.9% that the product is faulty”.

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
Part 1
Read the data and check the dimensions. How many rows and how many columns does the data have? You could use e.g. the dim() command.

library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.4     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.2     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

# 1

car_data <- readRDS("../../Causal_Data_Science_Data/car_prices.rds")
car_data <- na.omit(car_data)
cat("Dimensions of the data:", dim(car_data), "\n")

#> Dimensions of the data: 181 22




Part 2
Use appropriate commands to get a more detailed look at the data. What data types do you see? How do numbers differ from strings regarding their data type?

# 2

summary(car_data) # may also use str(car_data)

#>   aspiration         doornumber          carbody           drivewheel       
#>  Length:181         Length:181         Length:181         Length:181        
#>  Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   Class :character  
#>  Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character  
#>                                                                             
#>                                                                             
#>                                                                             
#>  enginelocation       wheelbase        carlength        carwidth    
#>  Length:181         Min.   : 86.60   Min.   :141.1   Min.   :60.30  
#>  Class :character   1st Qu.: 94.50   1st Qu.:166.3   1st Qu.:64.00  
#>  Mode  :character   Median : 96.50   Median :173.0   Median :65.40  
#>                     Mean   : 98.21   Mean   :173.3   Mean   :65.74  
#>                     3rd Qu.:100.40   3rd Qu.:180.2   3rd Qu.:66.50  
#>                     Max.   :120.90   Max.   :208.1   Max.   :72.30  
#>    carheight       curbweight    enginetype        cylindernumber    
#>  Min.   :47.80   Min.   :1488   Length:181         Length:181        
#>  1st Qu.:52.00   1st Qu.:2122   Class :character   Class :character  
#>  Median :53.70   Median :2410   Mode  :character   Mode  :character  
#>  Mean   :53.58   Mean   :2521                                        
#>  3rd Qu.:55.50   3rd Qu.:2910                                        
#>  Max.   :59.80   Max.   :4066                                        
#>    enginesize     fuelsystem          boreratio         stroke    
#>  Min.   : 61.0   Length:181         Min.   :2.540   Min.   :2.07  
#>  1st Qu.: 98.0   Class :character   1st Qu.:3.150   1st Qu.:3.08  
#>  Median :120.0   Mode  :character   Median :3.310   Median :3.23  
#>  Mean   :127.1                      Mean   :3.325   Mean   :3.23  
#>  3rd Qu.:141.0                      3rd Qu.:3.590   3rd Qu.:3.40  
#>  Max.   :326.0                      Max.   :3.940   Max.   :4.17  
#>  compressionratio   horsepower       peakrpm        citympg     
#>  Min.   : 7.000   Min.   : 48.0   Min.   :4200   Min.   :13.00  
#>  1st Qu.: 8.500   1st Qu.: 70.0   1st Qu.:4800   1st Qu.:19.00  
#>  Median : 9.000   Median : 95.0   Median :5200   Median :24.00  
#>  Mean   : 8.848   Mean   :106.2   Mean   :5182   Mean   :24.85  
#>  3rd Qu.: 9.400   3rd Qu.:116.0   3rd Qu.:5500   3rd Qu.:30.00  
#>  Max.   :11.500   Max.   :288.0   Max.   :6600   Max.   :49.00  
#>    highwaympg        price      
#>  Min.   :16.00   Min.   : 5118  
#>  1st Qu.:25.00   1st Qu.: 7609  
#>  Median :30.00   Median : 9980  
#>  Mean   :30.48   Mean   :12999  
#>  3rd Qu.:34.00   3rd Qu.:16430  
#>  Max.   :54.00   Max.   :45400

head(car_data)



  



Has 22 Variables with
aspiration, doornumber, carbody, drivewheel, enginelocation, enginetype, cylindernumber, fuelsystem with character values,
and wheelbase, carlength, carwidth, carheight, curbweight, enginesize, boreratio, stroke, compressionratio, horsepower, peakrpm, citympg, highwaympg, price with numeric values.


Part 3
Run a linear regression. You want to explain what factors are relevant for the pricing of a car.

# 3
car_model <- lm(price ~ doornumber + carbody + enginetype + fuelsystem + stroke + horsepower + citympg, data = car_data)
summary(car_model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ doornumber + carbody + enginetype + fuelsystem + 
#>     stroke + horsepower + citympg, data = car_data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -8922.8 -1774.7   -15.5  1466.0 16355.9 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                  Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)       4992.75    6211.58   0.804 0.422701    
#> doornumbertwo     -539.74     902.44  -0.598 0.550614    
#> carbodyhardtop   -3617.15    2267.11  -1.595 0.112551    
#> carbodyhatchback -6461.38    1753.77  -3.684 0.000312 ***
#> carbodysedan     -4771.37    1848.61  -2.581 0.010736 *  
#> carbodywagon     -6128.24    2032.18  -3.016 0.002978 ** 
#> enginetypedohcv  -9993.95    4639.52  -2.154 0.032711 *  
#> enginetypel       4884.77    2028.64   2.408 0.017168 *  
#> enginetypeohc     3202.33    1323.44   2.420 0.016640 *  
#> enginetypeohcf    1565.76    1759.84   0.890 0.374935    
#> enginetypeohcv    2557.31    1602.92   1.595 0.112570    
#> fuelsystem2bbl    -153.25    1314.25  -0.117 0.907316    
#> fuelsystemmfi    -7560.37    4217.62  -1.793 0.074908 .  
#> fuelsystemmpfi   -1676.81    1515.73  -1.106 0.270251    
#> fuelsystemspdi   -6473.78    1931.46  -3.352 0.000999 ***
#> fuelsystemspfi     452.35    4125.97   0.110 0.912835    
#> stroke            -697.37    1245.17  -0.560 0.576210    
#> horsepower         173.88      16.93  10.268  < 2e-16 ***
#> citympg           -166.47      96.59  -1.723 0.086716 .  
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 3879 on 162 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.792,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.7689 
#> F-statistic: 34.27 on 18 and 162 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


With some limited knowledge about cars, I think the factors mentioned above are relevant to a car price. I will use horsepower for further analysis.


Part 4
Choose one regressor and

explain what data type it is and what values it can take on
what effect it has on the price and what changing the value would have as a result
whether its effect is statistically significant.

Choosing “horsepower”

# 4

# data type it is and what values it can take on
str(car_data$horsepower)

#>  num [1:181] 111 111 154 102 115 110 110 110 140 160 ...

# effect it has on the price and what changing the value would have as a result
summary(car_model)$coefficients['horsepower',]

#>     Estimate   Std. Error      t value     Pr(>|t|) 
#> 1.311579e+02 1.480934e+01 8.856434e+00 1.669974e-15

# statistically significant
summary(car_model)$coefficients['horsepower','Pr(>|t|)']

#> [1] 1.669974e-15




Part 5
Add a variable seat_heating to the data and assign a value TRUE for all observations. You can use e.g. df %>% mutate(new_variable = value). Assign it to a new object and run a regression. What coefficient do you get for the new variable seat_heating and how can you explain it?

# 5

# Add variable 'seat_heating' and run a regression
car_prices_new <- car_data %>%
  mutate(seat_heating = TRUE) %>%
  na.omit()

# Run a regression with the new variable
model_new <- lm(price ~ doornumber + carbody + enginetype + fuelsystem + stroke + horsepower + citympg + seat_heating, data = car_prices_new)

summary(car_prices_new$seat_heating)

#>    Mode    TRUE 
#> logical     181

summary(model_new)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ doornumber + carbody + enginetype + fuelsystem + 
#>     stroke + horsepower + citympg + seat_heating, data = car_prices_new)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -8922.8 -1774.7   -15.5  1466.0 16355.9 
#> 
#> Coefficients: (1 not defined because of singularities)
#>                  Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)       4992.75    6211.58   0.804 0.422701    
#> doornumbertwo     -539.74     902.44  -0.598 0.550614    
#> carbodyhardtop   -3617.15    2267.11  -1.595 0.112551    
#> carbodyhatchback -6461.38    1753.77  -3.684 0.000312 ***
#> carbodysedan     -4771.37    1848.61  -2.581 0.010736 *  
#> carbodywagon     -6128.24    2032.18  -3.016 0.002978 ** 
#> enginetypedohcv  -9993.95    4639.52  -2.154 0.032711 *  
#> enginetypel       4884.77    2028.64   2.408 0.017168 *  
#> enginetypeohc     3202.33    1323.44   2.420 0.016640 *  
#> enginetypeohcf    1565.76    1759.84   0.890 0.374935    
#> enginetypeohcv    2557.31    1602.92   1.595 0.112570    
#> fuelsystem2bbl    -153.25    1314.25  -0.117 0.907316    
#> fuelsystemmfi    -7560.37    4217.62  -1.793 0.074908 .  
#> fuelsystemmpfi   -1676.81    1515.73  -1.106 0.270251    
#> fuelsystemspdi   -6473.78    1931.46  -3.352 0.000999 ***
#> fuelsystemspfi     452.35    4125.97   0.110 0.912835    
#> stroke            -697.37    1245.17  -0.560 0.576210    
#> horsepower         173.88      16.93  10.268  < 2e-16 ***
#> citympg           -166.47      96.59  -1.723 0.086716 .  
#> seat_heatingTRUE       NA         NA      NA       NA    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 3879 on 162 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.792,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.7689 
#> F-statistic: 34.27 on 18 and 162 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


As seen in summary of regression model “seat_heatingTRUE” with NA is what we get - indicates that this categorical variable (seat_heating) has only one level, that is value “TRUE”. This is proved with summary statement above this.
